coredata.dc:title: Recombination kinetics of molecules with anisotropic reactivity and interaction potential. Exact solution for a small reactive region
coredata.dc:creator: Shushin, A.I.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The Smoluchowski equation for a pair of molecules with anisotropic reactivity and interaction potential is solved in the limit of a small reactive region (small reactive patches). In the steady-state case steric factors are calculated using this solution. The kinetics of geminate pair recombination is also obtained and analyzed in detail.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 130, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 October 1986 RECOMBINATION KINETICS OF MOLECULES WITH ANISOTROPIC REACTIVITY AND INTERACTION POTENTIAL. EXACT SOLUTION FOR A SMALL REACTIVE REGION A.I. SHUSHIN Institute of Chemical Physics, Academy of Sciences, GSP-1, 117977 Moscow, USSR Received 3 June 1986; in final form 25 July 1986 The Smoluchowski equation for a pair of molecules with anisotropic reactivity and interaction potential is solved in the limit of a small reactive region (small reactive patches). In the steady-state case steric factors are calculated using this solu- tion. The kinetics of geminate pair recombination is also obtained and analyzed in detail. 1. Introduction Recently considerable interest has been shown in studying the reactions of molecules with an anisotropic reactivity (AR) and interaction [1-12]. The common- ly used theoretical approach in describing the recombi- nation kinetics is based on the Smoluchowski equation (SE) for the pair distribution function of recombining molecules. In refs. [1-8] simplified models have been utilized to find numerically the steady-state solution of the SE. The exact analytical solutions which have been ob- tained [9-12] are only applicable to the steady-state regime and are too cumbersome for both qualitative analysis and quantitative interpretation of the experi- mental results. Simple approximate expressions for the recombination rate constants (RRC) have been ob- tained [11,12] within the closure approximation [13, 14]. Unfortunately, the CA leads to a rather complex expression for the RRC in the most interesting case when both molecules display AR and, secondly, the accuracy of the closure approximation is somewhat unclear even in the steady-state case and completely uncertain in the non-stationary case. In this paper the analytical solution of the SE is ob- tained in the limit of small active surface size (the di- mensions of the patches are small). In section 3, simple expressions for the RRCs are obtained in some limit- ing cases. The interpolation formula for the RRC is derived within the closure approximation. Isotropic, as well as strongly anisotropic interactions, are taken into account. In section 4 the SE is solved and the geminate recombination kinetics are found. It will be shown that this type of kinetics becomes exponential provided there is a moderately strong and highly aniso- tropic interaction between the molecules. 2. General backgrounds Let q = (r, ft^ ,ftg) be the vector characterizing relative position and orientations of the molecules A and B (fig. 1). Eq. (1) is defined outside the sur- face S(fl) of closest approach, a small part of which Q(g) corresponds to the relative positions of the reac- tive molecules. For simplicity, the molecules are con- sidered to be spherical with radii R^ and .Kg. The RRC in the case of one molecule with AR Suppose initially that the molecule with the Ar, for example A, is rigidly oriented and u(q) = 0. The surface S(q) can be approximated by a plane in the small region near Q. As for Q itself we have no information on its shape and assume it to be a semispheroid with semi- axis c and b (fig. 2). Such a shape is rather flexible and enables us to solve the SE analytically. The boundary conditions are satisfied automatically. The solution in spheroidal coordinates [15] is ^c^K^-c2)1/2 X {^ - arctg[(6/c)2 - l]-1}-^)-1. (3) This formula reproduces the well-known limiting ex- pressions [9] and shows that the RRC depends on the anisotropy of the surface Q only slightly. Rotational diffusion of the molecule A results in the diffusion of the surface Q with diffusion coefficient DQ =R2Dr^ in the plane S. Thus the relative diffusion of the point and the surface Q becomes anisotropic with diffusion coefficients D^ = D + DQ in the plane and D perpendicular to it. The corresponding anisotrop- ic SE can be reduced to the isotropic one by the replace- ment z = (D/Dg)1/^', where z is the axis normal to S. The surface Q transforms into a new semispheroidal surface with semi-axes b' = b and c = (D^/D^^c > c. From eq. (3) we get (4) For c = 0 this formula coincides with that obtained in the CA. Eq. (4) is applicable when F < 1. 4. The geminate recombination kinetics Consider the case of two molecules with AR. The kinetics at times t < TR = D^j. g is obtained by solu- tion of the SE in the rectangular coordinates x. The operator 5 and the boundary conditions are given in eq. (6). We have no information on the initial distri- bution p(x, 0) = PQ(X). Fortunately, at times t>r^= ct2|Df. g the shape of the kinetic curves does not depend'on po(x), but only on their amplitudes. At this stage we should prescribe whether the mole- cules interact or not. (1) Let u(q) = 0. Then the abovementioned ampli- tudes are determined by the probability?^ {pg} of escaping to infinity. It is easily seen that ifa^^R the long time tail cannot be observed experimentally even for moderately large a^("sQA). This means that the geminate recom- bination kinetics of highly anisotropic molecules can be considered to be exponential if the interaction po- tential is highly anisotropic. 456 Appendix The formulation of the closure approximation is the following K=V^, T,=7;1 fdx'T(x) Vr 00 = F;1 f^'f^ fdxGQ(x,x',t), (Al) V, 0 V, where V^ is the reaction volume, Go(x,x',t) is the Green's function of two freely diffusing molecules. It can be simplified by noting that the main assumption in deriv- ing (A 1) is the weak dependence of T(x') on x' in the volume V^. Thus, with the same accuracy, we may omit the integration over x' and put x = XQ with XQ being any point in V^. Consider the most interesting cases of four- and five- dimensional spaces. Let the volume V^ be a cylinder with projection on the planes (x^,x^) and (x^,x^) being circles of radii r^ and /g respectively (in four- dimensional space) and that on the axis ^5 = x^ being 2dyf (in five-dimensional space). head.ce:title: Recombination kinetics of molecules with anisotropic reactivity and interaction potential. Exact solution for a small reactive region

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institute of Chemical Physics, Academy of Sciences, GSP-1, 117977 Moscow, USSR

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The Smoluchowski equation for a pair of molecules with anisotropic reactivity and interaction potential is solved in the limit of a small reactive region (small reactive patches). In the steady-state case steric factors are calculated using this solution. The kinetics of geminate pair recombination is also obtained and analyzed in detail.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: A.I. Shushin, Khim. Fiz., to be published.
